senses.definition: the round object used for controlling the direction in which a car, etc. or ship moves

examples.x: Always keep both hands on the wheel.
Never get behind the wheel if you're too tired.
This is the first time I've sat behind the wheel since the accident.
A car swept past with Laura at the wheel.
Do you want to take the wheel (= drive) now?
She fell asleep at the wheel and crashed into a tree.

senses.definition: a car

examples.x: At last he had his own wheels.

senses.definition: a flat, round part in a machine

examples.x: gear wheels

senses.definition: an organization or a system that seems to work like a complicated machine that is difficult to understand

examples.x: the wheels of bureaucracy/commerce/government
It was Rob's idea. I merely set the wheels in motion (= started the process).

senses.definition: having the number or type of wheels mentioned

examples.x: a sixteen-wheeled lorry

senses.definition: a car, bicycle, etc. with the number of wheels mentioned

examples.x: a three-wheeler

senses.definition: a space in the body of a vehicle over a wheel, like an arch in shape
a device that is attached to the wheel of a car that has been parked illegally, so that it cannot be driven away
a neck injury caused when your head moves forward and back suddenly, especially in a car accident

examples.x: He suffered whiplash injuries in the crash.

senses.definition: to have many bends and twists

examples.x: The path wound down to the beach.
A wooden staircase winds up to the attic.
The king's funeral procession wound slowly through city.
The river winds its way between two meadows.

senses.definition: to wrap or twist something around itself or something else

examples.x: He wound the wool into a ball.
Wind the bandage around your finger.
He wound the bandage tightly around his ankle.
They wind individual strands of fibre together to make home-made rope.

senses.definition: to operate a tape, film, etc. so that it moves nearer to its ending or starting position

examples.x: He wound the tape back to the beginning.
Wind forward to the bit where they discover the body.
With these cameras, after you click the shutter, you have to wind the film on.

senses.definition: to make a clock or machine work by turning a knob, handle, etc. several times; to be able to be made to work in this way

examples.x: He had forgotten to wind his watch.
It was one of those old-fashioned gramophones that winds up.

senses.definition: to turn a handle several times

examples.x: You operate the trapdoor by winding this handle.

senses.definition: having a curving and twisting shape Winding

examples.x: a long and winding road
The walk follows a winding path through the forest.

senses.definition: a long metal part with a rubber edge that moves across a windscreen to make it clear of rain, snow, etc.
the window across the front of a vehicle
a glass or plastic screen that provides protection from the wind, for example at the front of a motorcycle
one of the parts of the body of a bird, insect or bat that it uses for flying

examples.x: The swan flapped its wings noisily.
wing feathers

senses.definition: the wing of a chicken, etc. eaten as food

examples.x: We ordered the fried chicken wings.
First, fry the chicken wings in the oil until they begin to brown.

senses.definition: one of the large flat parts that stick out from the side of a plane and help to keep it in the air when it is flying

examples.x: Salvage teams have been able to recover part of the wing of the plane.
The right wing grazed the runway on landing.

senses.definition: a part of a large building that sticks out from the main part

examples.x: the east wing
the new wing of the hospital
Our rooms were in the west wing.

senses.definition: a part of a car that is above a wheel

examples.x: There was a dent in the nearside wing.

senses.definition: one section of an organization that has a particular function or whose members share the same opinions

examples.x: The radical wing of the party was dissatisfied with the policies.
The political wing of the National Resistance Army entered into negotiations with the government.
They're on the left wing of the Labour Party.

senses.definition: either of the attacking players who play towards the side of the playing area in sports such as football (soccer) or hockey
the far left or right side of the sports field

examples.x: He plays on the wing.

senses.definition: the area at either side of the stage that cannot be seen by the audience

examples.x: She watched every performance from the wings.

senses.definition: a mirror that sticks out from the side of a vehicle and allows the driver to see behind the vehicle
a large vehicle designed for people to live and sleep in when they are camping; a type of RV
a long metal part with a rubber edge that moves across a windscreen to make it clear of rain, snow, etc.

examples.x: Cars were coming past with their wipers going.

senses.definition: a ship that has sunk or that has been very badly damaged

examples.x: They're going to try and raise the wreck from the seabed.

senses.definition: a car, plane, etc. that has been very badly damaged in an accident crash

examples.x: Two passengers are still trapped in the wreck.
She was pulled from the burning wreck by firefighters.

senses.definition: a person who is in a bad physical or mental condition

examples.x: Physically, I was a total wreck.
The experience left her an emotional wreck.
The interview reduced him to a nervous wreck.

senses.definition: a vehicle, building, etc. that is in very bad condition

examples.x: The house was a wreck when we bought it.
They still hoped to salvage something from the wreck of their marriage.

senses.definition: an accident in which a vehicle hits something, for example another vehicle, usually causing damage and often injuring or killing the passengers

examples.x: a car/train wreck

senses.definition: the parts of a vehicle, building, etc. that remain after it has been badly damaged or destroyed

examples.x: A few survivors were pulled from the wreckage.
Pieces of wreckage were found ten miles away from the scene of the explosion.
Could nothing be rescued from the wreckage of her dreams?

senses.definition: a vehicle that has been so badly damaged in an accident that cannot be repaired or would cost more to repair than to replace

examples.x: She survived the crash with minor injuries, but the car was a write-off.

senses.definition: a period of time during which you do not achieve anything

examples.x: With meetings and phone calls, yesterday was a complete write-off.

senses.definition: an act of cancelling a debt and accepting that it will never be paid
(in the UK) a yellow line painted at the side of a road to show that you can only park your car there at particular times or for a short time

examples.x: double yellow lines (= two lines that mean you cannot park there at all)

senses.definition: to produce or provide something, for example a profit, result or crop

examples.x: Higher-rate deposit accounts yield good returns.
The research has yielded useful information.
These trees no longer yield fruit.
The project is expected to yield good returns in future.

senses.definition: to stop resisting something/somebody; to agree to do something that you do not want to do

examples.x: After a long siege, the town was forced to yield.
He reluctantly yielded to their demands.
I yielded to temptation and had a chocolate bar.

senses.definition: to allow somebody to win, have or take control of something that has been yours until now

examples.x: He refused to yield up his gun.
The universe is slowly yielding up its secrets.
archaeological remains which are yielding up secrets from long ago

senses.definition: to move, bend or break because of pressure

examples.x: Despite our attempts to break it, the lock would not yield.

senses.definition: to allow vehicles on a bigger road to go first

examples.x: Yield to oncoming traffic.
a yield sign

senses.definition: an area of road marked with broad black and white lines where vehicles must stop for people to walk across
used to describe a vehicle that does not produce gases that cause pollution

examples.x: Zero-emission cars—including all electric cars—are exempt from car tax.
